description.narrative: - Household surveys using Akvo Flow: to gain understanding into a number of people that for example make use of safe drinking water and/or use improved sanitation facilities - Focused group discussions: to gain understanding into reasons behind a change (or why change did not happen) - Key informant interviews: to gather further information on specific topics or to cross check information collected - Secondary data: are to be used to support other evidence and preferably in comparison with baseline or midterm data.

- To conduct outcome monitoring based on the indicators applicable to BSP by using Akvo Flow - To inform the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as well as the partners and in particular the Dutch WASH Alliance members and other stakeholders on the outcome of RAIN’s projects under DWA five-year programme.
As part of the Dutch WASH Alliance programme 2011 - 2015
BSP-Nepal as part of the Dutch WASH alliance programme in Nepal, will conduct an outcome measurement of all its projects during the period 2011 - 2015 in Salyan and Palpa district.

In order to get a holistic figure of BSP-Nepal’s implementation work under the Dutch WASH Alliance (2011-2014), BSP-Nepal will conduct a mapping exercise using the Akvo FLOW as part of the outcome monitoring of its projects under the DWA.

In the context of Nepal and it’s foundation in 2004, RAIN has been working with its partners to promote, develop, spread and implement rainwater harvesting systems. Having initiated the promotion of RWH in Nepal as decentralized drinking water source and for enabling use of biogas in water scarce areas, today the technology is being promoted for multiple uses to ensure livelihood enhancement. Presently the integration of 3R (retention, recharge and reuse) principals is accepted for enabling access to water from different natural sources for variety of purposes like domestic and productive use ranging from drinking, sanitation, energy generation to food security and climate change adaptation as it is more related to the enhancement of indigenous knowledge .
